Ionic liquids-based ionic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs): A single catalyst with dual active centers for the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide Yunchang Fan Writing – review & editing Methodology a Huijie Shan Investigation Data curation a Yuanfeng Wu Investigation a Haibao Zhu Writing – original draft Methodology b ⁎ a College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Polytechnic University, Jiaozuo 454003, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Polytechnic University Jiaozuo 454003 China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Polytechnic University, Jiaozuo 454003, China b School of Public Health, Hangzhou Medical College, Hangzhou 310013, China School of Public Health, Hangzhou Medical College Hangzhou 310013 China School of Public Health, Hangzhou Medical College, Hangzhou 310013, China ⁎ Corresponding author. The conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates is a promising approach for chemical fixation of CO2 and the development of robust catalysts is still a big challenge. This work suggested ionic liquids (ILs)-based ionic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) using a bisimidazole-based IL as organic link. The introduction of ILs made the ionic MOFs dual active center catalysts (ILs and metal ions). Experiments indicated that the catalytic activity of the ionic MOFs using indium ion (In3 +) as metal center was superior to that of those with zinc ion (Zn2+) as metal node due to the stronger electrophilicity of In3+ than Zn2+, making In-based ionic MOFs more effectively activate the epoxide ring, which was verified by the results of theoretical calculations. Moreover, a high chloropropene carbonate yield (98.1 %) could be obtained without the addition of co-catalysts under the optimum conditions (0.1 MPa CO2, 5.4 % catalyst, 80 °C for 7 h). Graphical Abstract Keywords Ionic liquids (ILs) Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) Cycloaddition reaction Carbon dioxide Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) concentration in the atmosphere has increased by approximately 30 % in the past decades mainly due to the overuse of fossil fuels, causing a significant increase in the Earth's surface temperature [1]. The storage and utilization of CO2 are the important approach for limiting global warming and the chemical fixation of CO2 to produce the high value-added chemicals, cyclic carbonates, via cycloaddition of epoxides and CO2 is one of attractive solutions for the conversion of CO2 due to the excellent atom economy of cycloaddition reaction and the wide applications of cyclic carbonates such as electrolytes in secondary batteries, intermediates and solvents in chemical industry [2,3]. In general, catalysts are required to accelerate the reaction rate of cycloaddition due to the thermodynamic stability and kinetically inert nature of CO2. In this context, a variety of catalysts including ionic liquids (ILs) [4–6], nitrogen rich porous organic polymer (NRPOP) [7], microporous zinc phosphonate (ZnPS) [8] and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [9–11] have been applied in the cycloaddition of epoxides and CO2. Undoubtedly, ILs are efficient catalysts for the conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates, they still suffer from the difficult separation of ILs from the reaction media due to the miscibility of ILs with epoxides and cyclic carbonates [4–6]. Furthermore, NRPOP and ZnPS have proven to be promising catalysts for the chemical fixation of CO2 under mild conditions. However, they involve the use of the co-catalyst, tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) [7,8]. As far as MOFs are concerned, although they are insoluble in the cycloaddition reaction systems, co-catalysts such as TBAB [9,10] and hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) [11] are usually needed because of the low activity of MOFs. Based on the above results, the combination of ILs and MOFs may be an efficient strategy to boost the conversion of CO2. For example, Hu et al. used the IL, tributyldodecylphosphonium bromide ([P12,4,4,4]Br) as catalyst and the MOF, MIL-53(Cr) (MIL = Materials of Institute Lavoisier) as co-catalyst to construct a dual catalytic system for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides and the yields of cyclic carbonates above 96 % can be obtained under 1.0 MPa of CO2 and 100 °C due to the synergistic effects of the active site chromium of MIL-53(Cr) and the IL, [P12,4,4,4]Br [12]. This exciting finding suggests the feasibility of the combination of MOFs and ILs for the conversion of CO2, but simply physically mixing ILs with MOFs still faces the difficulty of recovering the ILs. The grafting of ILs onto MOFs via chemical bonds has been proven to be one of the favorable approaches for the easy recovery of ILs [13–20]. Feng and coworkers synthesized a triethylenediamine-based bicationic IL-grafted MIL-101(Cr) (noted as Cl[TNH2]Cl@MIL-101(Cr)) via post-modification method, i.e., MIL-101(Cr) was first prepared and then triethylenediamine and chloroethylamine were grafted onto the ligand of MIL-101(Cr) through covalent bonds to produce Cl[TNH2]Cl@MIL-101(Cr). This IL-modified MOF exhibits high catalytic activity for the CO2 conversion and a yield of chloropropene carbonate (CPC) as high as 97.8 % is obtained at mild conditions (104.5 °C, 1.07 MPa of CO2) without the addition of any co-catalysts [17]. Lin et al. used mixed ligands consisting of terephthalic acid and the IL 1,3-dicarboxymethylimidazolium bromide to prepare an IL modified UiO-66 type MOF. It shows excellent catalytic activity upon the cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide with a conversion rate of 98.2 % under optimized conditions (2.2 MPa of CO2 and 110 °C) [18]. These interesting findings clearly suggest that the IL-modified MOFs are effective catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2. However, they are usually prepared via the hydrothermal methods that were operated at high temperature and elevated pressure. Besides, the cycloaddition reactions are usually carried out under high CO2 pressure. Therefore, the exploration of ILs-based MOFs that are synthesized under mild conditions and have high activity for the conversion of CO2 under low CO2 pressure is still a great challenge. Inspired by the above works, the MOFs that only use ILs as ligands might have higher catalytic activity as compared to the IL-modified MOFs. Therefore, the aims of this work are to develop a facile method to prepare ILs-based ionic MOFs and evaluate their catalytic performance for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Indium bromide (InBr3, 99.9 %), zinc bromide (ZnBr2, 99 %), epichlorohydrin (ECH, ≥ 99.5 %), styrene oxide (SO, 98 %), benzyl glycidyl ether (BZGE, 99 %), glyoxal aqueous solution (40 %), 1-propyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide ([PMIM]Br, 99 %), indium nitrate pentahydrate (In(NO3)3·5 H2O, 99.99 %), 2-methylimidazole (2-MIM, 98 %) and 1-(3-aminopropyl)imidazole (≥ 97 %) were supplied by Macklin Inc. (Shanghai, China). Formaldehyde aqueous solution (≥ 36 %), glycidyl phenyl ether (GPE, >99.0 %), imidazole-2-carboxaldehyde (IMCA, ≥ 98 %), zinc nitrate hexahydrate (Zn(NO3)2·6 H2O, 99 %) and acetic acid (HAc, ≥ 99.5 %) were obtained from Aladdin Scientific Corp. (Shanghai, China). 1-Aminopropyl-3-methylimidazolium bromide ([APMIM]Br, 98 %) was purchased from Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (Lanzhou, China). All the other chemicals used are of analytical grade unless stated otherwise. 2.2 Synthesis of 1,3-bis(N-propylimidazole)imidazolium acetate ([BPIM-IM]Ac) The IL, [BPIM-IM]Ac was prepared as follows ( Fig. 1): 6.3 g of 1-(3-aminopropyl)imidazole, 9.1 g of HAc, 2.1 g of formaldehyde aqueous solution, 3.6 g of glyoxal aqueous solution and 30 mL of water were mixed under stirring at room temperature (25 °C) for 8 h, followed by the removal of water by distillation. The resultant raw product was washed three times with ethyl acetate and subsequently dried at 70 °C for 4 h to remove residual solvents. After dissolving this raw product in water, 0.1 mol L–1 of NaOH was added to adjust the aqueous pH to approximately 8. After removal of water by distillation, the raw product was washed with acetone and subsequently dried at 70 °C. The IL, [BPIM-IM]Ac was finally obtained as a viscous brown liquid with a yield of 94 %. The chemical structure of [BPIM-IM]Ac was identified by the proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR) spectroscopy and the result is demonstrated in Fig. S1 in the Supplementary Material (SM). 2.3 Preparation of ILs-based ionic MOFs For a typical procedure, 0.75 mmol of [BPIM-IM]Ac was dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol, which is noted as A and 0.75 mmol of InBr3 was dissolved in 5 mL of ethanol, which is marked as B. The A and B solutions were mixed under stirring at room temperature for 10 min and the resultant white powder was washed by ethanol and acetone, respectively. After vacuum drying at 100 °C for 8 h, the resultant MOF, noted as InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1, was obtained as a white powder with a yield of 82 %. When the initial molar ratios of InBr3 to [BPIM-IM]Ac are 1: 3 and 3: 1, the prepared MOFs are noted as InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-2 (43 % yield) and InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-3 (42 % yield), respectively. When ZnBr2 was used as raw material, the synthesis of MOFs followed a similar procedure. The synthesized MOFs are noted as ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 (72 % yield), ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-2 (19 % yield) and ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-3 (53 % yield) respectively when the initial molar ratios of ZnBr2 to [BPIM-IM]Ac, 1: 1, 1: 3 and 3: 1, are adopted. Details about the characterization of the ILs-based ionic MOFs are depicted in the SM. The IL-grafted In/Zn-based MOFs (IL-In/Zn-MOFs) and the In/Zn-based MOF-IL composites (IL@In/Zn-MOFs) were prepared and characterized according to the reported methods [19,20] and details are listed in SM (Figs. S2-S4). 2.4 Analysis of the composition of ILs-based ionic MOFs The ILs-based ionic MOFs were first dissolved in water and then the contents of In and Zn were determined by an Optima 8000 inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Perkin Elmer, Waltham, MA, USA). The concentrations of Br– and Ac– were measured by ion chromatography (IC) and the levels of [BPIM-IM]+ were analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC). The detailed information about the operating conditions of HPLC and IC are listed in the SM. 2.5 Cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides Briefly, 10 mmol of ECH and 50 mg of catalyst were added into a Schlenk tube (50 mL) sealed with a latex balloon filled with CO2 and then the Schlenk tube was flushed three times with CO2 to replace the air inside. Subsequently, the cycloaddition reaction was performed at 80 °C for 7 h under stirring. After cycloaddition reaction is completed, solid catalyst and liquid product were separated via centrifugation. The CPC yield and selectivity of cyclocarbonate were obtained using the reported 1H NMR spectroscopy [19,21]. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were used to explore the cycloaddition mechanism and the detail description for the DFT calculations is listed in SM. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of ILs-based ionic MOFs The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the ILs-based ionic MOFs demonstrated in Fig. 2 indicate that the ILs-based ionic MOFs have two diffraction peaks appearing at 11.2°–12.5° and 22.8°–24.5° respectively, which are similar to the XRD patterns of zeolite imidazole frameworks (ZIFs) [22,23]. Meanwhile, the broad peak shape indicates the amorphous characteristics of the ILs-based ionic MOFs [24,25], meaning that it is difficult to obtain their detailed structure information. To further explore the structures of the ILs-based ionic MOFs, the experiments of ICP-OES, IC and HPLC were carried out. The experimental results indicate that the chemical compositions of the ILs-based ionic MOFs can be written as In[BPIM-IM]Br3.5Ac0.5 (InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1), In[BPIM-IM]2Br3Ac2 (InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-2), In[BPIM-IM]Br3.8Ac0.2 (InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-3), Zn[BPIM-IM]1.4Br2.8Ac0.6 (ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1), Zn[BPIM-IM]1.6Br2.8Ac0.8 (ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-2) and Zn[BPIM-IM]1.2Br3Ac0.2 (ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-3), respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 3 and Figs. S5-S9, the ILs-based ionic MOFs show plate-like morphologies, meanwhile, the elements, In, Br, C, N, O and Zn, are homogeneously distributed in the ILs-based ionic MOFs as suggested by the mapping images of energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). In addition, the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the synthesized ILs-based ionic MOFs were measured and the results elucidated in Fig. 4 (panels a and b) indicate that all the ILs-based ionic MOFs display type IV isotherms with type H3 hysteresis loops, suggesting the presence of slit-like mesopores formed by the non-rigid aggregates of plate-like particles, as observed in the SEM images (Fig. 3 and Figs. S5-S9) [26,27]. The BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) surface areas, pore sizes (BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) method) and pore volumes (BJH method) of the synthesized ILs-based ionic MOFs are listed in Table 1. It is observed that the amorphous ILs-based ionic MOFs have smaller specific surface areas (4.3 m2 g–1 to 37.8 m2 g–1), which is in line with the properties of amorphous MOFs [28,29]. To further investigate the molecular structure of the synthesized ionic MOFs, their Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were measured and the results are demonstrated in Fig. 4c and Fig. S10. The bands at around 3411–3544 cm–1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of OH group of water adsorbed on the MOFs and the peaks appear at 3114–3121 cm–1 and 2950–2952 cm–1 are ascribed to the CH stretching vibration of imidazolium/imidazole ring and the stretching vibration of CH2 group, respectively [30,31]. The peaks at 1610–1622 cm–1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of CO and the three peaks at 1562–1565 cm–1, 1522–1527 cm–1 and 1094–1101 cm–1 are related to the bending and stretching vibrations of the imidazolium/imidazole rings [30–32]. The bands at approximately 1451–1454 cm–1 are related to CH2 asymmetric bending vibration [30–32], while, the peaks located at in the range of 500–536 cm–1 correspond to the stretching vibration of M-N bonds (M = In/Zn) [33,34]. Additionally, the thermal stability of the synthesized ILs-based ionic MOFs were explored by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and the results demonstrated in Fig. 4d and Fig. S11 indicate that significant weight losses occur between 263 °C to 500 °C for the ILs-based ionic MOFs and the onset temperatures (T onset) are in the range of 263 °C to 366 °C, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of the imidazole/imidazolium ring of the IL, [BPIM-IM]Ac [35–37]. Besides, it can be seen from Fig. 4d and Fig. S11 that the T onset values of the Zn-based ionic MOFs are higher than the In-based counterparts. This may be explained by the fact that Zn(II) and the imidazole unit of [BPIM-IM]Ac are borderline Lewis acid and borderline base respectively according to the “Hard and Soft Acid-base Theory” (HSAB), whereas In(III) is hard Lewis acid [38,39]. This suggests that the interaction between Zn2+ and [BPIM-IM]+ is stronger than that between In3+ and [BPIM-IM]+, that is, Zn-based ionic MOFs have higher thermal stability [36,37]. Meanwhile, another interesting phenomenon that can be observed from Fig. 4d and Fig. S11 is that the T onset values are highly related to the molar ratio of [BPIM-IM]+ to metal: higher [BPIM-IM]+/Zn2+ molar ratio results to lower T onset value (T onset (ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-3) > T onset (ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1) > T onset (ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-2); T onset (InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-3) ≈ T onset (InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1) > T onset (InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-2)), which may be ascribed to the fact that high [BPIM-IM]+-to-metal ratio reduces the interaction between the imidazole unit of [BPIM-IM]+ and metal (In3+ or Zn2+) and consequently decreases the thermal stability [36,37,40,41]. Finally, the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was used to obtain the chemical information of the ionic MOFs and the results are illustrated in Fig. 5 and Figs. S12-S16. As can be seen from these figures, each C 1 s XPS spectrum can be deconvoluted into three peaks, which are ascribed to C-C (284.8 eV), C-N/C=N (285.9 eV – 286.1 eV) and O-CO/C=NIL cation (287.7 eV – 288.6 eV) groups (Fig. 5 and Figs. S12-S16, panels a) [42–44]. Each N 1 s spectrum can be resolved into three peaks located at 398.0 eV – 399.1 eV (C=N-M, M = In/Zn), 399.3 eV – 399.6 eV (C-N) and 401.0 eV – 401.3 eV (N IL cation), respectively (Fig. 5 and Figs. S12-S16, panels b) [43–45]. The peaks of C=N-M appearing at 398.0 eV – 399.1 eV indicate the bonding form of M-N2 in the MOFs (i.e., two nitrogen atoms coordinate with one metal ion) [46,47]. The peak of C=N of the ionic MOFs with higher metal/[BPIM-IM]+ ratio appears at higher binding energy compared with the ones with lower metal/[BPIM-IM]+ ratio (e.g., 399.0 eV (InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1, InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-3) versus 398.4 eV (InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-2) and 399.0 eV – 399.1 eV (ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1, ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-3) versus 398.0 eV (ZnBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-2)), which may be ascribed to the significant electron transfer of N atom of the C=N bond to the metal for the ionic MOFs with high metal/[BPIM-IM]+ ratio [48,49]. The peaks appearing at 531.2 eV – 531.6 eV in the O 1 s XPS spectra (Fig. 5 and Figs. S12-S16, panels c) are the typical signals of acetate [44] while the peak at 68.2 eV – 68.9 eV (Fig. 5 and Figs. S12-S16, panels d) corresponds to the signal of Br 3d [50]. The In 3d XPS spectra (Fig. 5 and Figs. S12-S13, panels e) involve two main peaks at 444.9 eV – 445.0 eV (In 3d5/2) and 452.5 eV – 452.7 eV (In 3d3/2) [51,52] while the Zn 2p peaks (Figs. S14-S16, panels e) located at 1044.5 eV – 1044.8 eV and 1021.5 eV – 1021.8 eV can be assigned to Zn 2p1/2 and Zn 2p3/2, respectively [51]. Based on the XPS analysis and the compositions of the ILs-based ionic MOFs, it may be deduced the possible coordination environments of metal node. That is, the center metal (In3+or Zn2+) coordinates with two nitrogen atoms, three bromide ions and one acetate ion to constitute an octahedral geometry (Fig. S17), which is similar to the coordination structure of In-tris (4-(1H-imidazol-1-yl) phenyl) amine MOFs [53]. 3.2 Screening of the ILs-based ionic MOFs and the catalytic mechanism In this work, 6 ILs-based ionic MOFs were used to catalyze the cycloaddition of CO2 and ECH and the results demonstrated in Fig. 6a indicate that all the ionic MOFs exhibit high catalytic selectivity (≥ 98 %) towards the CO2 cycloaddition. The catalytic performance of In-based ionic MOFs (CPC yield, ≥ 96.7 %) is much higher than that of the Zn-based counterparts (CPC yield, 12.7 % – 77.6 %) although the former has lower CO2 adsorption capacity as compared to the latter (Table 1), which may be ascribed to the fact that In3+ has stronger Lewis acid than Zn2+ [38,39], making the ring-opening procedure of ECH more efficient [54,55]. To gain deeper insight into the difference in catalytic ability between In-based ionic MOFs and the Zn-based ones, theoretical studies were performed using DFT calculations. For simplicity, a single repeating unit of the ILs-based ionic MOFs containing IL unit and metal (In3+ or Zn2+) was opted to explain the catalytic mechanism and the energetic profile of the intermediates and transition states along with the reaction routes are shown in Fig. 7. The energies of the ILs-based ionic MOFs (catalysts) were preset to zero and the transformation of CO2 follows the reported mechanism, i.e., takes place in three steps: (I) ring opening of ECH, (II) CO2 insertion and (III) ring-closure to produce CPC, among which ring opening of ECH is rate-determining step (transition state 1 (TS1) and intermediate 1 (Int1) in Fig. 7) [15,55,56]. As illustrated in Fig. 7, In-based ionic MOF exhibits lower energy barriers than the Zn-based counterpart because In3+ is stronger electrophile than Zn2+ since the former can supply more positive charge. Additionally, it has been reported that ILs can also be used as catalysts for the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides with CO2 because the acidic proton at the C2 position (C2-H) of the imidazolium ring can effectively activate the epoxides by lowering the energy barrier of ring opening via the hydrogen bonding with epoxides [4,56,57]. So, the ILs-based ionic MOFs can regarded as catalysts with dual active centers and the plausible mechanism for the cycloaddition reaction catalyzed by the ILs-based ionic MOFs is suggested in Fig. 8. In the initial step, metal ion (In3+ or Zn2+) and the C2-H of the imidazolium ring interacts with the oxygen atom of ECH and activate the epoxide ring (step 1), followed by the formation of a ring-opening intermediate via bromine ion attacking (step 2). Thereafter, this intermediate interacts with the CO2 molecule to produce a new alkyl carbonate-based intermediate (step 3), which finally affords the CPC and regenerates the catalyst via the ring-closure reaction (steps 4–5). Based on the above discussion, the In-based ionic MOFs show higher catalytic performance (Fig. 6a) and InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 is thus selected as the optimal catalyst and used for the following experiments because it has the highest CPC yield among the In-based ionic MOFs. 3.3 Effects of the operating conditions Generally, the operating conditions including reaction temperature, reaction time and catalyst dosage are the key parameters affecting the catalytic performance. As demonstrated in Fig. 6b, the CPC yield increases from 50.9 % to almost 100 % with selectivity above 98 % when rising the reaction temperature and time from 70 °C/3 h to 90 °C/7 h. Taking into account both CPC yield and energy consumption, lower reaction temperature and shorter time, 80 °C/7 h, are regarded as the optimum reaction condition because a CPC yield as high as 98.1 % can be obtained under this condition. Fig. 6c suggests that without the presence of catalyst, the CPC yield is zero and an increase in the CPC yield happens when increasing the catalyst dosage because a large amount of catalyst can provide ample active sites. Since 5.4 % (weight ratio of catalyst to ECH) can provide a CPC yield as high as 98.1 %, it is selected as the optimum catalyst dosage. 3.4 Catalytic performance towards other epoxides To explore the versatility of InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1, the conversions of additional epoxides including SO, BZGE and GPE were studied under the optimum conditions and the results elucidated in Fig. 6d indicate that InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 exhibits good catalytic activity towards BZGE and GPE with the yields of the corresponding cyclic carbonates in the range of 76.3–86.9 % (selectivity, > 98 %). The low conversion (5 % yield with 99 % selectivity) of SO may be related to the low reactivity of the β-carbon atom of SO arising from the large steric hindrance and strong conjugative effect of the benzene ring of SO [5,54,58]. 3.5 Comparison of catalytic performance with reported catalysts Recently, the ILs functionalized Zn/In-based MOFs that were prepared by physical mixing of ILs with MOFs (IL@Zn/In-MOFs) or chemical grafting of ILs onto MOFs (IL-Zn/In-MOFs) have been applied to the CO2 cycloaddition [19,20]. As demonstrated in Fig. S18, all the MOFs exhibit high catalytic selectivity (≥ 97 %) while the catalytic performance of the suggested ionic MOFs InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 is higher than that of the IL@Zn/In-MOFs and IL-Zn/In-MOFs. In addition, the IL leakage of InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 (18.4 %) in the reaction process is lower than IL@Zn/In-MOFs (IL leakage, 99.8 % for IL@Zn-MOFs and 76.7 % for IL@In-MOFs) and IL-Zn/In-MOFs (IL leakage, 79.5 % for IL-Zn-MOFs and 24.6 % for IL-In-MOFs), suggesting the better stability of InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1. Furthermore, the preparation of the IL-grafted MOFs was usually operated at elevated temperature and long reaction time (e.g., 90 °C for 24 h, followed by 60 °C for 24 h [19]) while the synthesis of InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 can be conducted at mild conditions (room temperature for 10 min). Furthermore, a series of Zn-/In-based MOFs including aNH2-MIL-68 (In) (amorphous amino-functionalized MIL-68 (In)) [59], In2(BDC)3ox (1,4-dicarboxybenzene (H2BDC) and oxalic acid (H2ox) as ligands) [60], CPM-5-PhDA (In) (diamine-modified In-trimesic acid MOFs) [61], ZnLoba (di(pyridin-4-yl)naphthalene-2,6-dicarboxamide (L) as ligand and 4,4′-oxybisbenzoic acid (H2oba) as coligand) [62], IL-ZIF (Zn) (noncrystalline ZIFs (Zn) tethered with ILs) [63], ZIF-8 (Zn) [64], ZIF-90-IL (Zn) (ILs functionalized ZIF-90) [65], [Zn(CPMT)(bipy)] n (CPMT = 1-(4-carboxyphenyl)-5-mercapto-1Htetrazole, bipy = 4,4′-bipyridine) [9] and Zn(Py)(Atz) (H2Py = 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid, Hatz = 3-Amino-1,2,4-triazole) [66] have been used to catalyze the cycloaddition of ECH with CO2 and the results listed in Table 2 indicate that the catalytic activity (expressed by turnover frequency (TOF)) of InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 is higher than most of the In/Zn-based MOFs (entries 1, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9) and is lower than that of In2(BDC)3ox (entry 2), CPM-5-PhDA (In) (entry 3) and ZIF-90-IL (Zn) (entry 8). However, In2(BDC)3ox involves the use of the co-catalyst TBAB (3.5 %) [60] while higher CO2 pressure and temperature are needed for CPM-5-PhDA (In) (1.0 MPa/100 °C) [61] and ZIF-90-IL (Zn) (2.5 MPa/90 °C) [65] as compared to InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 (0.1 MPa/80 °C). Besides, the reported Zn- and In-based MOFs except for IL-ZIF (Zn) (entry 6) are synthesized at higher temperature (50 °C – 130 °C) and longer reaction time (14.5 h – 5 days) compared with InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1. Although IL-ZIF (Zn) (entry 6) can be prepared at room temperature, it still requires a longer reaction time (6 h) as compared to InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 (10 min). Ease of preparation, without the need of extra co-catalyst and mild operating conditions are the advantages of the suggested IL-based ionic MOF InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1. 4 Recyclability of catalyst The recyclability of InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 was also examined under the optimum conditions. After cycloaddition reaction, the InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 phase was washed with acetone, dried at 100 °C for 8 h under vacuum and subsequently reused for the next catalytic run. The recycling experiments ( Fig. 9a) indicated that after four repeated runs, the selectivity keeps constant (> 98 %) while the CPC yield drops, ascribing to the leakage of the ligand ([BPIM-IM]Ac) in MOFs as mentioned above. Meanwhile, it can be seen from Fig. 9b that the intensities of the XRD peaks of the recycled InBr-[BPIM-IM]Ac-1 is lower than those of the fresh one, suggesting the changes in the chemical structure. This may be explained by the fact that ECH is a polar compound [67] and consequently the polar ligands in MOFs tend to leak out [68]. The utility of ligands with weak polarity to prepare MOFs might be one of the ways to avoid the leakage of ligands and related work is undergoing. 5 Conclusions In this work, 6 ionic MOFs using a bisimidazole-based IL as organic link were synthesized and their catalytic performance towards the ECH-CO2 cycloaddition reaction was explored. The experimental results showed that In-based ionic MOFs exhibited higher catalytic performance than the Zn-based ones due to the stronger Lewis acidity of In3+ as compared to Zn2+, which led to In-based ionic MOFs owning lower energy barrier in the reaction path as suggested by the DFT calculations. Meanwhile, In-based ionic MOFs had dual active centers (IL and In3+), endowing them high catalytic activity. Compared with the reported MOF-based catalysts, the suggested ILs-based ionic MOFs were easy to prepare (room temperature for 10 min), had high catalytic activity and could be operated under mild conditions without the addition of extra co-catalysts. These findings suggest that ILs-based ionic MOFs exhibit great application potential in the chemical fixation of CO2. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of CO2 to cyclic carbonates is a promising approach for chemical fixation of CO2 and the development of robust catalysts is still a big challenge. This work suggested ionic liquids (ILs)-based ionic metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) using a bisimidazole-based IL as organic link. The introduction of ILs made the ionic MOFs dual active center catalysts (ILs and metal ions). Experiments indicated that the catalytic activity of the ionic MOFs using indium ion (In3 +) as metal center was superior to that of those with zinc ion (Zn2+) as metal node due to the stronger electrophilicity of In3+ than Zn2+, making In-based ionic MOFs more effectively activate the epoxide ring, which was verified by the results of theoretical calculations. Moreover, a high chloropropene carbonate yield (98.1 %) could be obtained without the addition of co-catalysts under the optimum conditions (0.1 MPa CO2, 5.4 % catalyst, 80 °C for 7 h).
